text: Mr. Nageotte, you may proceed whenever you're ready.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Nageotte, we granted certiorari only on the jury trial issue in this case.
Yes, Your Honor, I'm simply trying to briefly summarize the facts.

Mr. Nageotte, if the language of the statute had made clear that the so-called civil sanction was to be related to disgorgement of economic benefit for example, would you think the Seventh Amendment would then guarantee a right to trial by jury?
That would really depend on the precise language used.
Well, you would concede that it could be an equitable remedy?
--Yes.
Well, is it possible that we could interpret this statute as essentially one for that type of relief even though it's not express?
Justice O'Connor, I don't believe that that could be done in this case for this very specific reason.
Would you clarify one thing factually for me?
--Yes, Your Honor, he was.
Mr. Nageotte, do I understand you to say that there is no discretion as to whether or not a civil penalty shall be imposed under the statute?
That's correct, Justice Scalia.
Says that any person who commits a violation shall be subject to a civil penalty.
--Yes, sir.
Yes, shall be subject to.

Shall be subject, I read the words, "shall be" to require the imposition of some penalty and that's the government's position in most of these cases, that it's not a discretionary item, that the court must impose some civil penalty in each case.
If someone is subject to deportation, it means he must be deported.
Well, if you read, if you read it together with the criminal penalties which are provided in 33 U.S.C. 1319(c), the criminal penalties provide for a willful or negligent violation.
I agree that you're subject to them.
No, Your Honor, these are... this is simply from my experience in trying these cases at the district court level.
--Well, if Congress had vested the authority in an administrative agency to impose a civil fine, I don't suppose you'd be here.
--That's absolutely correct, Your Honor.
And so you are in effect saying Congress made its choice.
Well absolutely, Your Honor.
Well, xxx but is there a jury trial.
--Yes, Justice White, and it was, and they knew, I mean they knew, we have, what we have is a coin that has heads and tails.
Is there any administrative mechanism for imposing civil penalties under the Clean Water Act?
--No, sir.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
You haven't addressed it at all.
That is what has been held and that is the xxx.
--Have you addressed whether it must be assessed.
I'm addressing it right now.
Unless there are any questions from the Court I really have nothing further to add.
Mr. Nageotte, are you really serious in your claim that the jury would have to set, if you have a right to jury trial, you have a right to have the jury set the fine?
Yes, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr. Nageotte.
